questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressive fatigue and painful swelling of her right knee for 3 weeks. She works as a professional ballet dancer and says, “I'm always trying to be in shape for my upcoming performances.” She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 45 kg (99 lb); BMI is 17 kg/m2. Physical examination shows tenderness and limited range of motion in her right knee. Oral examination shows bleeding and swelling of the gums. There are diffuse petechiae around hair follicles on her abdomen and both thighs. Laboratory studies show a prothrombin time of 12 seconds, an activated partial thromboplastin time of 35 seconds, and a bleeding time of 11 minutes (N = 2–7). Arthrocentesis of the right knee shows bloody synovial fluid. The patient’s condition is most likely associated with a defect in a reaction that occurs in which of the following cellular structures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The lysosome is the site at which macromolecules (e.g., misfolded proteins, cell debris) are degraded; it is not involved in collagen synthesis. Defects in lysosome function occur in lysosomal storage diseases, whereas this patient's symptoms are characteristic of scurvy.

B) INCORRECT:

The final modification and packaging of the procollagen triple helix into transport vesicles are the last steps prior to its secretion into the extracellular space (i.e., exocytosis) and take place in the Golgi apparatus. These processes do not require vitamin C.
Image Description:

The Golgi apparatus is composed of cisternae, which are arranged in a convex cis or a concave trans face. The cis face receives transport vesicles from transitional ER (1). These contain cargo proteins as well as other proteins of the ER, which are sent back to the transitional ER. Cargo proteins are further transported from one cistern to the other and are modified (e.g., glycosylated) during the process (2). At the trans face, vesicles detach and reach the cell membrane, where they fuse together. Through fusion, membrane proteins (3) or secretory proteins (4) are transported to their destination. Other vesicles contain acidic enzymes labeled with mannose-6-phosphate and are detached from the Golgi apparatus by the protein clathrin in order to form primary lysosomes (5).

C) CORRECT:

Hydroxylation of lysine and proline residues in the rough endoplasmic reticulum of fibroblasts is an essential step in collagen synthesis, as hydroxylysine-lysine cross-links between tropocollagen molecules are needed in order to form firm collagen fibrils. This reaction is catalyzed by prolyl and lysyl hydroxylase and requires vitamin C as a cofactor. Consequently, vitamin C deficiency, as seen in this patient, reduces the tensile strength of collagen and results in typical manifestations of scurvy, which include bleeding diathesis due to weakened vessel walls (potentially leading to hemarthrosis and mucosal bleeding), delayed wound healing, swollen gums, perifollicular petechiae, a weakened immune response, and fatigue (due to anemia).
Image Description:

Collagen biosynthesis starts with the translation (1) at the rough ER, during which the polypeptide chain of the collagens is modified (Hydroxylation, 2). For attaching the OH groups, vitamin C is necessary as a cofactor for lysyl hydroxylase and prolyl hydroxylase. Next, by attaching sugar molecules, hydroxylysine residues are glycosylated (3). Three procollagen chains form a triple helix (4). These very large molecules are enclosed in vesicles, transported to the cell membrane via the Golgi apparatus and secreted via exocytosis in the extracellular space (5). At this stage, the collagen triple helix is further processed: The propeptides at the end of the collagen propeptide chains are split off (6). Next, the formed tropocollagens are cross-linked to fibrils (fibrillogenesis, 7). In the extracellular space, several of these fibrils form collagen fibers (8).

Various conditions are the result of defective collagen synthesis. Examples can be found in the overlay.

D) INCORRECT:

The transcription of collagen DNA to mRNA is the first step in collagen synthesis and takes place in the nucleus of fibroblasts. This process is mainly mediated by RNA polymerase II and does not require vitamin C.

E) INCORRECT:

The extracellular space is the site of tropocollagen formation, cross-linking, and collagen fiber formation. Following its secretion into the extracellular space, the procollagen triple helix is cleaved at the C-terminus and N-terminus to form water-insoluble tropocollagen. Adjacent tropocollagen molecules are reinforced through the cross-linking of hydroxylysine residues (catalyzed by copper-dependent lysyl oxidase) to form collagen fibrils. Finally, several collagen fibrils accumulate to form collagen fibers. Vitamin C does not play a role in any of the steps taking place in the extracellular space.

F) INCORRECT:

Free ribosomes float within the cytosol and are the site of synthesis of intracellular proteins (cytosolic, nuclear, and mitochondrial proteins). However, collagen is a secreted protein and is therefore translated by ribosomes bound to the rough endoplasmic reticulum (site of synthesis of secretory proteins) instead. Vitamin C does not play a role in the translation step of collagen synthesis.
questions.hint: This underweight patient's hemarthrosis, perifollicular petechiae, and bleeding gums are likely due to impaired collagen synthesis secondary to vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) from malnutrition.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department after falling out from a chair and injuring her right leg. During the past 2 years, she has had two long bone fractures. She is at the 5th percentile for height and 20th percentile for weight. Her right lower leg is diffusely erythematous. The patient withdraws and yells when her lower leg is touched. A photograph of her face is shown. An x-ray of the right lower leg shows a transverse mid-tibial fracture with diffusely decreased bone density. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The vascular type of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (type 4) arises from an autosomal mutation in collagen type 3. This condition manifests predominantly in the cardiovascular system and often goes undiagnosed until it becomes apparent through some sort of vascular damage/injury (e.g., aortic dissection, ruptures arterial aneurysm, subarachnoid hemorrhage). The child presents with easy bruising, as evidenced by the ecchymosis, which is also a feature of Ehlers-Danlos type 4. However, the child's history of frequent fractures after minor trauma, the blue sclerae, and growth retardation are not consistent with this condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Type 5 collagen is a regulator of type 1 collagen fibrillogenesis. Type 5 collagen defects usually manifest as classic Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which is characterized by chronic joint and bone issues. Rather than frequent bone fractures, the major symptoms are joint instability, early onset of osteoarthritis, hyperflexible joints, and scoliosis.

C) CORRECT:

A mutation in type 1 collagen causes osteogenesis imperfecta type 1, the mildest and most common form of osteogenesis imperfecta. In fact, some patients with osteogenesis imperfecta type 1 appear normal and without obvious deformities to the casual observer despite requiring special accommodations for their bone fragility. This child presents with blue sclera, short stature, and growth retardation, recurrent fractures from minor falls, and decreased bone density – all classic symptoms of osteogenesis imperfecta.

D) INCORRECT:

Mutations to the genes encoding type 4 collagen can present as Alport syndrome. This disorder usually affects boys, who present with intermittent gross hematuria, hearing loss, and ocular disturbances, none of which are seen here. Recurrent bone fractures, growth retardation, and blue sclerae are not features of Alport syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Type 2 collagen defects predominantly affect tissues such as cartilage and the vitreous humor. Various conditions are associated with type 2 collagen defects (e.g., hypochondrogenesis, Kniest dysplasia, or osteoarthritis) and these differ substantially in presentation and age of onset. While some conditions could explain the growth retardation observed in this patient (e.g., hypochondrogenesis, Kniest dysplasia), blue sclerae and recurrent bone fractures in an otherwise healthy child would not be consistent with any type 2 collagen defect.
questions.hint: This patient presents with growth retardation, recurrent bone fractures, blue sclera, and osteopenia, all of which are consistent with the diagnosis of osteogenesis imperfecta.

questions.text: An investigator is studying collagen synthesis in human fibroblast cells. Using a fluorescent tag, α-collagen chains are identified and then monitored as they travel through the rough endoplasmic reticulum, the Golgi apparatus, and eventually into the extracellular space. Which of the following steps in collagen synthesis occurs extracellularly?

choices.text: Cleavage of procollagen C- and N-terminals

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The glycosylation of specific hydroxylysine residues in pro-α chains is the third step in collagen synthesis. This step occurs intracellularly in the rough endoplasmic reticulum. Impaired glycosylation is implicated in osteogenesis imperfecta.

B) INCORRECT:

The hydroxylation of proline and lysine is the second step in collagen synthesis. It is a vitamin C-dependent process that occurs intracellularly in the rough endoplasmic reticulum. In cases of scurvy, hydroxylation of proline and lysine is impaired.

C) CORRECT:

Procollagen that is formed in the ribosomes is transported to the extracellular space via Golgi bodies. The cleavage of the procollagen C- and N-terminals to form insoluble tropocollagen occurs in the extracellular space. This cleavage is carried out by proteases that are only found outside the cell. The final step of collagen synthesis, which is the formation of covalent lysine-hydroxylysine crosslinks between tropocollagen by the enzyme lysyl oxidase, also occurs extracellularly.
Image Description:

Collagen biosynthesis starts with the translation (1) at the rough ER, during which the polypeptide chain of the collagens is modified (Hydroxylation, 2). For attaching the OH groups, vitamin C is necessary as a cofactor for lysyl hydroxylase and prolyl hydroxylase. Next, by attaching sugar molecules, hydroxylysine residues are glycosylated (3). Three procollagen chains form a triple helix (4). These very large molecules are enclosed in vesicles, transported to the cell membrane via the Golgi apparatus and secreted via exocytosis in the extracellular space (5). At this stage, the collagen triple helix is further processed: The propeptides at the end of the collagen propeptide chains are split off (6). Next, the formed tropocollagens are cross-linked to fibrils (fibrillogenesis, 7). In the extracellular space, several of these fibrils form collagen fibers (8).

Various conditions are the result of defective collagen synthesis. Examples can be found in the overlay.

D) INCORRECT:

Formation of the triple-helix structure of procollagen results from hydrogen and disulfide bonds between α-collagen chains. This process occurs intracellularly mainly in the rough endoplasmic reticulum. Failure to form this triple helix can lead to osteogenesis imperfecta

E) INCORRECT:

The translation of the pro-α chains of collagen (preprocollagen) occurs intracellularly. mRNA is shuttled from the nucleus to the rough endoplasmic reticulum, where bound ribosomes translate the mRNA into preprocollagen.
questions.hint: A defect in this step is implicated in certain subtypes of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman with depression comes to the physician because of easy bruising and bleeding of her gums for the past 2 months. She has been living alone since the death of her husband 1 year ago. She appears thin and has temporal wasting bilaterally. Physical examination shows bruises on her lower legs, swollen gums, and petechiae on the hard palate. This patient's symptoms are most likely due to defective synthesis of a substance that is composed primarily of which of the following amino acids?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Collagen is a protein with the repeating amino acid sequence (Gly-X-Y). Since glycine is always on the first position of this triplet, it makes up for ⅓ of amino acids in a collagen molecule. On position X there is most commonly proline (second most common: lysine or hydroxylysine) and on position Y most commonly hydroxyproline (second most common: lysine or hydroxylysine). Vitamin C is needed as a cofactor in collagen synthesis for the hydroxylation of proline residue to hydroxyproline and of lysine residue to hydroxylysine.

B) INCORRECT:

Proline is a nonessential amino acid with hydrophobic properties. Although it is part of collagen, only 13.5% of total amino acids in collagen are proline.

C) INCORRECT:

Tyrosine is a nonessential amino acid with hydrophilic properties. It is part of signal-transduction pathways (tyrosine kinase) and plays an important role in the synthesis of catecholamines. It is not part of collagen.

The last step in the norepinephrine synthesis from tyrosine requires vitamin C as a cofactor (dopamine → norepinephrine).

D) INCORRECT:

Lysine is a basic, essential amino acid with hydrophilic properties. Although it is part of collagen, only 3 or 4% of total amino acids in collagen are lysine.

E) INCORRECT:

Arginine is a basic, conditionally essential amino acid. It plays an important role in the urea cycle and is part of histone proteins. It is not found in collagen.

F) INCORRECT:

Alanine is a nonessential, nonpolar amino acid; it is not part of collagen.

Alanine plays an important role in the glucose-alanine cycle (Cahill cycle), which allows the body to produce glucose from alanine created during muscle protein degradation.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms (swollen gums, bruises, mucosal bleeding) in the setting of undernutrition (thin appearance, temporal wasting) are suggestive of vitamin C deficiency. Vitamin C is essential for the synthesis of collagen.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the structural integrity of collagen. Human fibroblasts are cultured on a medium and different enzymes are applied. One of the cultures is supplemented with an enzyme that inhibits the formation of hydrogen and disulfide bonds between collagen α-chains. Which of the following processes is most likely to be impaired as a result?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The bone matrix is composed predominantly of type 1 collagen fibers. An important step in the formation of collagen is the synthesis of procollagen, which has a triple helical structure, from preprocollagen. This process occurs inside the rough endoplasmic reticulum and involves the formation of hydrogen and disulfide bonds between collagen α-chains. Impaired formation of type 1 collagen is characteristic of osteogenesis imperfecta, which is typically caused by autosomal dominant defects in the COL1A1 and COL1A2 genes.

Children with osteogenesis imperfecta can be treated with bisphosphonates, which increase cortical thickness.
Image Description:

Collagen biosynthesis starts with the translation (1) at the rough ER, during which the polypeptide chain of the collagens is modified (Hydroxylation, 2). For attaching the OH groups, vitamin C is necessary as a cofactor for lysyl hydroxylase and prolyl hydroxylase. Next, by attaching sugar molecules, hydroxylysine residues are glycosylated (3). Three procollagen chains form a triple helix (4). These very large molecules are enclosed in vesicles, transported to the cell membrane via the Golgi apparatus and secreted via exocytosis in the extracellular space (5). At this stage, the collagen triple helix is further processed: The propeptides at the end of the collagen propeptide chains are split off (6). Next, the formed tropocollagens are cross-linked to fibrils (fibrillogenesis, 7). In the extracellular space, several of these fibrils form collagen fibers (8).

Various conditions are the result of defective collagen synthesis. Examples can be found in the overlay.

B) INCORRECT:

Relaxation of ligaments is primarily due to the elastic properties of elastin, not collagen. Elastin is composed of tropoelastin, which is crosslinked to allow elastin filaments a high degree of flexibility. Elastin filaments have the ability to stretch and recoil repeatedly without losing their structure. Conditions associated with defects in elastin formation include Menkes disease, Marfan syndrome, and Williams syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Osteoclasts are activated by a variety of stimuli, including the RANK ligand, parathyroid hormone, and interleukins (e.g., IL-1). Impaired osteoclast activity can be caused by certain drugs including denosumab, bisphosphonates, IL-1 receptor antagonists (e.g., anakinra), and estrogen derivatives. Impaired osteoclastic activity is also seen in patients with osteopetrosis. However, osteoclast activation does not rely on the formation of hydrogen or disulfide bonds between collagen α-chains.

D) INCORRECT:

The internal elastic lamina (IEL) is composed predominantly of elastin, not collagen. Impaired formation of the IEL in segments of an artery is seen in fibromuscular dysplasia, and fragmentation of a previously healthy IEL can be seen in malignant hypertension as well as certain forms of vasculitis (e.g., giant cell arteritis). Collagen is a component of other parts of vascular tissue, including the basement membrane of the tunica intima (type 4 collagen), the tunica media (type 3 collagen), and the tunica adventitia (type 3 collagen).

E) INCORRECT:

Mineralization of the cartilage in epiphyseal growth plates by hypertrophic chondrocytes occurs as a precursor to secondary endochondral ossification. Hyaline cartilage, which is the type of cartilage in epiphyseal growth plates, contains type 2 collagen. However, cartilage mineralization of the growth plate is primarily driven by vitamin D and would occur independently of collagen formation. In patients with vitamin D deficiency, this process is impaired, leading to rickets or osteomalacia in severe cases.
questions.hint: Inhibition of disulfide bonds would impair the formation of the triple helix structure of collagen.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a 3-week history of abdominal distention and yellowing of the skin. He also has a 2-year history of progressively worsening breathlessness and cough. Three days after admission, he suddenly develops peritonitis and sepsis. Despite appropriate care, he dies. At autopsy, histopathological examination of liver and lung tissue shows periodic acid-Schiff-positive (PAS-positive) globules within periportal hepatocytes. Further analysis shows low levels of a protein that is responsible for the recoil of the lungs during expiration. Which of the following processes most likely contributes to the elastic properties of this protein?

choices.text: Arrangement in a triple helical structure

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Elastin is a stretchy protein that is abundant in skin, lungs, certain ligaments, vocal cords, and large (elastic) arteries. The elastic recoil of elastin is predominantly due to extracellular crosslinking of tropoelastin molecules. The crosslinks are formed by transglutaminase, which forms glutamyl-lysine bonds, and by lysyl oxidase, which catalyzes the oxidative deamination of nonhydroxylated lysine residues to form polylysine crosslinks. These crosslinks in elastin undergo nonenzymatic conversion to desmosine. The enzyme lysine oxidase is also responsible for crosslinking of tropocollagen molecules, but the crosslinks of collagen are formed from hydroxylated lysine residues.

Conditions associated with defects in elastin formation include Menkes disease, Marfan syndrome, and Williams syndrome.
Image Description:

Relaxed and stretched conformations of an elastin molecule

B) INCORRECT:

Hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues occurs during collagen synthesis. Elastin, on the other hand, is rich in nonhydroxylated proline and lysine residues.

C) INCORRECT:

Collagen has a triple helical structure. Elastin, on the other hand, does not have a triple helical structure. It is formed by amorphous aggregates of tropoelastin molecules that are enclosed within a sheath of fibrillin.

D) INCORRECT:

Formation of disulfide bridges occurs during collagen synthesis. Elastin, on the other hand, does not have disulfide bridges.

E) INCORRECT:

N-glycosylation is involved in the formation of the fibrillin sheath, which in turn forms a scaffold for tropoelastin assembly and contributes to the elastic recoil of elastin. However, N-glycosylation occurs on amino acids with nitrogen atoms in the side chain (e.g., asparagine, arginine); it does not occur on serine, which has a hydroxyl group on the side chain and, therefore, instead undergoes O-glycosylation. O-glycosylation does not play a role in the synthesis or the elastic recoil of elastin. However, O-glycosylation of hydroxylysine residues is an important step in procollagen synthesis.
questions.hint: Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency (AATD), which can result in early-onset emphysema and liver cirrhosis, is characterized by the presence of PAS-positive globules on liver biopsy. AAT normally hydrolyzes neutrophilic elastase in the lung. In the case of AATD, elastase activity in the lung is increased, and, consequently, the levels of elastin are decreased.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the rate of wound healing by secondary intention. He performs a biopsy of a surgically debrided wound 5 days and 60 days after the initial surgical procedure. Both biopsy specimens show an extracellular matrix protein that stains blue with the trichrome stain. Spectrometric analysis discloses that the protein has a supercoiled triple helical structure and exists in the specimens predominantly as one of two structural variants, A and B. Protein quantification assays reveal that the ratio of variant A to variant B content is high in the biopsy specimen obtained on day 5 and low in the specimen obtained on day 60. The variant A identified by the investigator is most abundant in which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The proliferative phase of wound healing begins during the first week after injury. During this phase, fibroblasts primarily produce type III collagen, which plays a role in granulation tissue formation. Reticular fibers, which can be found in the blood vessels, uterus, and fetal extracellular matrix, are also composed of type III collagen.

The remodeling phase of wound healing begins weeks to months after the initial injury. During this phase, fibroblasts replace type III collagen with type I collagen. The bone, dentin, and corneal stroma are examples of tissue rich in type I collagen.

B) INCORRECT:

The nucleus pulposus is rich in type II collagen, which does not play a significant role in wound healing.

C) INCORRECT:

The basal lamina is primarily composed of type IV collagen, which does not play a significant role in wound healing.

D) INCORRECT:

The corneal stroma (substantia propria) is composed primarily of type I collagen. This type of collagen is secreted by fibroblasts in the late (remodeling) stage of wound healing and is the variant B identified by the researcher.

E) INCORRECT:

Dentin is rich in type I collagen. This type of collagen is secreted by fibroblasts in the late (remodeling) stage of wound healing and is the variant B identified by the researcher.

F) INCORRECT:

The vitreous humor primarily contains type II collagen, which does not play a significant role in wound healing.

G) INCORRECT:

The lens capsule is rich in type IV collagen, which does not play a significant role in wound healing.
questions.hint: The protein that has a triple helical structure and is stained blue by a trichrome stain is collagen. Type III and type I collagen are primarily involved in wound healing. The ratio of type III to type I collagen in wound tissue changes depending on the phase of wound healing.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for evaluation of easy bruising. He has met all developmental milestones. Vital signs are within normal limits. He is at the 50th percentile for height and weight. Physical examination shows velvety, fragile skin that can be stretched further than normal and multiple ecchymoses. Joint range of motion is increased. A defect in which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

α-Collagen triple helix formation is disrupted in patients with osteogenesis imperfecta. Though this condition can manifest with easy bruising, skin hyperelasticity, and joint hypermobility, most patients also have a history of numerous fractures with minimal trauma. Other common manifestations include blue sclerae, hearing loss, and dental abnormalities.

B) INCORRECT:

α1-Antitrypsin production by the liver is reduced in patients with α1-antitrypsin deficiency. In severe cases, this condition can manifest with early liver dysfunction (e.g., hepatitis, cirrhosis) and panacinar emphysema. This condition does not cause easy bruising, skin hyperelasticity, and joint hypermobility.

C) INCORRECT:

Fibrillin-1 glycoprotein production is disrupted in patients with Marfan syndrome, which can also cause skin hyperelasticity and joint hypermobility. However, this patient lacks other characteristic manifestations of Marfan syndrome, including tall and slender stature, high-arched palate, arachnodactyly, pectus excavatum, and lens dislocation. Moreover, Marfan syndrome does not cause easy bruising.

D) INCORRECT:

Proline and lysine hydroxylation is impaired in patients with scurvy because vitamin C is a necessary cofactor in this process. Though this condition can manifest with easy bruising, patients also typically have signs and symptoms of malnutrition such as poor wound healing and an impaired immune response. This condition does not cause skin hyperelasticity or joint hypermobility.

E) CORRECT:

Ehlers-Danlos syndrome has several subtypes, all of which share the underlying mechanism of defective collagen synthesis and/or processing. In patients with impaired lysine-hydroxylysine cross-linking of tropocollagen (e.g., due to enzyme deficiencies), stable collagen fibrils cannot be formed, leading to the characteristic presentation seen in this patient. Defects in type III collagen and type V collagen can also cause this condition.

Problems with collagen cross-linking are also seen in Menkes disease due to decreased activity of lysyl oxidase.
Image Description:

Collagen biosynthesis starts with the translation (1) at the rough ER, during which the polypeptide chain of the collagens is modified (Hydroxylation, 2). For attaching the OH groups, vitamin C is necessary as a cofactor for lysyl hydroxylase and prolyl hydroxylase. Next, by attaching sugar molecules, hydroxylysine residues are glycosylated (3). Three procollagen chains form a triple helix (4). These very large molecules are enclosed in vesicles, transported to the cell membrane via the Golgi apparatus and secreted via exocytosis in the extracellular space (5). At this stage, the collagen triple helix is further processed: The propeptides at the end of the collagen propeptide chains are split off (6). Next, the formed tropocollagens are cross-linked to fibrils (fibrillogenesis, 7). In the extracellular space, several of these fibrils form collagen fibers (8).

Various conditions are the result of defective collagen synthesis. Examples can be found in the overlay.
questions.hint: This boy has findings consistent with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which typically manifests with easy bruising, skin hyperelasticity, and joint hypermobility.
